pullRequest.body:
Unify binary inf and min, as discussed in https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/.60sup.60.2F.60inf.60.20or.20.60max.60.2F.60min.60.20for.20set.20interval.20lemmas.3F.

---
Regressions: The instance for the product of metric spaces and some dependent instances are noncomputable now. I had the impression that noncomputability for reals is usual and unproblematic throughout mathlib, but could have a look at it otherwise.
Things that still need to be done: Optionally unify notation in some lemmas to always use min and max for total orders.
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
> The instance for the product of metric spaces and some dependent instances are noncomputable now.

It can be fixed by adjusting the priority of instances. But https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/issues/2905 causes the need to change the priority of instances of a lot of ordered algebraic typeclasses. You can also try to create shortcut instances only for `ENNReal` to see if it fixes everything.

> > The instance for the product of metric spaces and some dependent instances are noncomputable now.
> 
> It can be fixed by adjusting the priority of instances. But [leanprover/lean4#2905](https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/issues/2905) causes the need to change the priority of instances of a lot of ordered algebraic typeclasses. You can also try to create shortcut instances only for `ENNReal` to see if it fixes everything.

I wasn't able to create the shortcut instances (Max on R‚â•0 is still deduced from some noncomputable ordered algebra instance). And I do not know enough about the typeclass inference algorithm and the classes in mathlib to play around with priorities

### PR summary [543c823f68](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18707/commits/543c823f689f8752c8585c5b921720059aa17920)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph

|-|-|

</details>

`-- sup_eq_max`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

> (gave a review in person)

I think we misdiagnosed an issue: Max is still computable on the reals (and the LinearOrder uses the right fields). Previously, synthesizing Max on ‚Ñù‚â•0 used the same computable instance, but synthesizing Sup went through an instance for subtype semilattices, which for a reason unclear to me is noncomputable. Now only the second route remains. So, if one really wants to fix this, one probably would have to check why this lattice-theoretic instance is noncomputable.

pullRequest.title: chore: unify binary inf and min

> (gave a review in person)

I think we misdiagnosed an issue: Max is still computable on the reals (and the LinearOrder uses the right fields). Previously, synthesizing Max on ‚Ñù‚â•0 used the same computable instance, but synthesizing Sup went through an instance for subtype semilattices, which for a reason unclear to me is noncomputable. Now only the second route remains. So, if one really wants to fix this, one probably would have to check why this lattice-theoretic instance is noncomputable.
